OLO Description: Cite specific textual evidence to support analysis of primary and secondary sources.
Determine the central ideas of a primary or secondary source.
Identify the key details of information of a primary or secondary source.
Provide an accurate summary of a source distinct from prior knowledge or opinions.
Identify key steps in a text‰Ûªs description of a process related to history/social studies (e.g., how a bill becomes law, how interest rates are raised or lowered).
Determine the meaning of general academic words and phrases as they are used in a text.
Determine the meaning of words and phrases specific to the domains of history/social studies.
Describe how a text presents information (e.g., sequentially, comparatively, causally).
Identify aspects of a text that reveal an author‰Ûªs point of view or purpose (e.g., loaded language, inclusion or avoidance of particular facts).
Integrate visual information (e.g., in charts, graphs, photographs, videos, or maps) with other information in print and digital texts.
Distinguish among fact, opinion, and reasoned judgment in a text.
Analyze the relationship between a primary and secondary source on the same topic.
By the end of grade 8, read and comprehend history/social studies texts in the grades 6‰ÛÒ8 text complexity band independently and proficiently.
Cite specific textual evidence to support analysis of texts on science and technology.
Determine the central ideas of scientific and technical texts.
Determine the conclusions in scientific and technical texts.
Provide an accurate summary of the scientific or technical text distinct from prior knowledge or opinions.
Follow precisely a multistep procedure (e.g.conducting experiments, taking measurements, or performing technical tasks).
Determine the meaning of scientific symbols (e.g. symbols of elements, chemical formulae, temperature, and measurements)
Determine and distinguish the meaning of common and scientific nomenclature. ( e.g. coyote vs. Canis Latrans)
Determine the meaning of mathematical symbols as applied to scientific and technical texts.
Determine the meaning of domain-specific terms and words used in scientific and technical topics and texts relevant to grades 6-8.
Analyze the structure an author uses to organize a text on science and technology.
Analyze how major sections contribute to the whole text and support understanding of a scientific or technical topic.
Analyze the author‰Ûªs purpose in providing an explanation, describing a procedure, or discussing an experiment in a text.
Integrate quantitative or technical information expressed in words in a text with a version of that information expressed visually (e.g., in a flowchart, diagram, model, graph, or table).
Distinguish among facts, reasoned judgment based on research findings, and speculation in a text.
Compare and contrast information gained from experiments and simulations with that gained from reading a text on the same topic
Compare and contrast information gained from video and multimedia sources with that gained from reading a text on the same topic.
By the end of grade 8, read and comprehend science/technical texts in the grades 6‰ÛÒ8 text complexity band independently and proficiently.
Write arguments focused on discipline-specific content (e.g. history/social studies, science, technology).
Introduce claim(s) about a topic or issue (e.g. historic, scientific, technical).
Acknowledge and distinguish the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims on a discipline-specific topic or issue.
Organize the reasons and evidence logically to support claims about a topic or issue.
Support claim(s) with logical reasoning and rhetoric that demonstrate an understanding of the topic or text.
Support claim(s) with accurate data and evidence that demonstrate an understanding of the topic or text
Use words, phrases, and clauses to create cohesion in an argumentative text.
Use words, phrases, and clauses to clarify the relationships among claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence in an argumentative text.
Establish and maintain a formal style.
Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the argument presented.
Write informative/explanatory texts (e.g. narration of historical events, explanation of scientific procedures/ experiments, and description of technical processes).
Introduce a topic clearly, previewing what is to follow in a text.
Organize ideas, concepts, and information into broader categories as appropriate to achieving purpose.
Include formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., charts, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension.
Develop the topic with relevant, well-chosen facts, definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples.
Use appropriate and varied transitions to create cohesion
Use appropriate and varied transitions to clarify the relationships among ideas and concepts.
Use precise academic language to inform about or explain the topic.
Use domain-specific vocabulary to inform about or explain the topic.
Establish and maintain a formal style and objective tone.
Provide a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation presented.
Produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience.
With some guidance and support from peers and adults, develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach.
With some guidance and support from peers and adults focus on and address the task, purpose, and audience in writing.
Use technology in both localized computer files and shared online texts to produce and publish writing.
Use technology to present the relationship between ideas and information clearly.
Conduct short research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question)
Draw on several credible print and digital sources.
Generate additional related, focused research questions that allow for multiple avenues of exploration.
Evaluate the authority and reliability of both print and digital sources.
Gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources.
Assess the usefulness of each source in answering the research question.
Use advanced search terms and fields effectively to find relevant sources.
Integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas.
Avoid plagiarism when quoting or paraphrasing the data or conclusions of others.
Following a standard format for citation of quotations and sources.
Draw evidence from informational texts to support analysis reflection, and research.
Write routinely over extended time frames (time for reflection and revision  for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences.
Write routinely over shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences.
